data_functions module¶

data_functions.add_points_to_map(arr, map_obj, color='blue')¶

Add points from a numpy array to a folium map.

Parameters:

  • arr (numpy.ndarray) – Numpy array containing the points with columns ID, latitude, and longitude.

  • map_obj (folium.folium.Map) – Folium map object.

  • color (str) – Color for the points, default is “blue”.

Returns:

Always returns 0.

Return type:

int

data_functions.autocorr(data, name, cols)¶

Compute and plot the autocorrelation for time series data.

Parameters:

  • data (numpy.ndarray) – A numpy array with shape (tracks, locations, time, parameters). The data represents multiple tracks, with multiple locations, over time, and for various parameters.

  • name (list) – A string representing the title of the plots.

  • name – A list of strings representing the subtitles of the plots.

Returns:

A list of numpy arrays, where each array is the autocorrelation for a given parameter.

Return type:

list[numpy.ndarray]

Note

The function computes the autocorrelation for each parameter and location. It then plots the average autocorrelation for each parameter across all tracks and locations.

data_functions.check_nan(arr, cols=['MWD(° from north)', 'PWP(s)', 'SWH(m)', 'TWD(m)', 'WiD(° from north)', 'WiS(m/s)'])¶

Checks the number of NaN values in a provided numpy array.

Parameters:

arr (numpy.ndarray) – Numpy array with data.

Returns:

0 indicating success.

Return type:

int

data_functions.checkdim(target_contour, data_folder='../../data/20230608/TimeSeries_Data_20230607', parameter_types=['_MWD_', '_PWP_', '_SWH_', '_TWD_', '_WiD_', '_WiS_'])¶

Check if all the .csv files in the given directory have the same shape and if all tracks are the same.

Parameters:

  • target_contour (str) – Target contour to check.

  • data_folder (str) – Path to the data folder.

  • parameter_types (list of str) – List of parameter types to check.

Returns:

Maximum time dimension, space dimension, and track dimension found among all CSV files.

Return type:

tuple of int

data_functions.checkdup(arr)¶

Checks the percentage of duplicate data in the provided numpy array.

Parameters:

arr (numpy.ndarray) – Numpy array with data.

Returns:

Percentage of duplicated data.

Return type:

float

data_functions.convert_to_numpy(df)¶

Convert the DataFrame into a numpy array containing only ID, X, and Y columns.

Parameters:

df (pandas.DataFrame) – DataFrame to convert.

Returns:

Numpy array with columns ID, X, and Y.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

data_functions.get_elevation(lat, lon, api_key)¶

Get the elevation in meters for a given latitude and longitude using Google Maps Elevation API.

Parameters:

  • lat (float) – Latitude coordinate.

  • lon (float) – Longitude coordinate.

  • api_key (str) – API key for the Google Maps Elevation API.

Returns:

Elevation in meters or False if there’s an error.

Return type:

float or False

data_functions.get_elevation_for_array(arr, api_key)¶

Get elevation data for all points in a numpy array.

Parameters:

  • arr (numpy.ndarray) – Numpy array with columns ID, latitude, and longitude.

  • api_key (str) – API key for the Google Maps Elevation API.

Returns:

A new numpy array containing ID, latitude, longitude, and elevation columns.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

data_functions.haversine_distance(loc1, loc2)¶

Calculates the Haversine distance between two points on the Earth.

Parameters:

  • loc1 (list) – First location in the format [points ID, latitude, longitude].

  • loc2 (list) – Second location in the format [points ID, latitude, longitude].

Returns:

Distance in kilometers between the two points.

Return type:

float

data_functions.plot_elevation(data_array)¶

Plot the elevation values from a provided data array.

Parameters:

data_array (numpy.ndarray) – A numpy array where the first column represents IDs and the last column represents elevations. The array should be structured as [ID, …, Elevation].

Returns:

0 indicating success.

Return type:

int

Note

This function assumes that the elevation is the last column in the data_array. The plot generated will have IDs on the x-axis and elevations on the y-axis.

data_functions.plotarr(arr, cols=['MWD(° from north)', 'PWP(s)', 'SWH(m)', 'TWD(m)', 'WiD(° from north)', 'WiS(m/s)'])¶

Plots the quantiles (25%, 50%, 75%) and the mean for each feature in the given array.

Parameters:

arr (numpy.ndarray) – Numpy array with data.

Returns:

0 indicating success.

Return type:

int

data_functions.read_save(target_contour, savepath, track_dim, time_dim, space_dim, data_folder='../../data/20230608/TimeSeries_Data_20230607', parameter_types=['_MWD_', '_PWP_', '_SWH_', '_TWD_', '_WiD_', '_WiS_'])¶

Create a zero-filled array with the maximum dimension, then fill in the data from the .csv files.

Parameters:

  • target_contour (str) – Target contour to read.

  • savepath (str) – Path to save the numpy array.

  • track_dim (int) – Number of tracks.

  • time_dim (int) – Maximum number of time points.

  • space_dim (int) – Maximum number of space points.

  • data_folder (str) – Path to the data folder.

  • parameter_types (list of str) – List of parameter types to read.

Returns:

0 indicating success.

Return type:

int

data_functions.track_order(target_contour, data_folder='../../data/20230608/TimeSeries_Data_20230607', parameter_types=['_MWD_', '_PWP_', '_SWH_', '_TWD_', '_WiD_', '_WiS_'])¶

Check the order of the tracks for a given contour.

Parameters:

  • target_contour (str) – Target contour to check order for.

  • data_folder (str) – Path to the data folder.

  • parameter_types (list of str) – List of parameter types to check.

Returns:

Order of the tracks for the given contour if same order.

Return type:

list of str
